trans-unit.source: Migrating to Azure Premium Storage | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Migrating to Azure Premium Storage | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Migrate to Azure Premium Storage for high-performance, low-latency disk support for I/O intensive workloads running on Azure Virtual Machines.
trans-unit.target: Migrate to Azure Premium Storage for high-performance, low-latency disk support for I/O intensive workloads running on Azure Virtual Machines.

trans-unit.source: Migrating to Azure Premium Storage
trans-unit.target: Migrating to Azure Premium Storage

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: Premium Storage stores data on the latest technology Solid State Drives (SSDs), delivers high-performance, low-latency disk support for I/O intensive workloads running on Azure Virtual Machines.
trans-unit.target: Premium Storage stores data on the latest technology Solid State Drives (SSDs), delivers high-performance, low-latency disk support for I/O intensive workloads running on Azure Virtual Machines.

trans-unit.source: With Premium Storage, your applications can have up to 32 TB of storage per VM and achieve 50,000 IOPS (input/output operations per second) per VM with extremely low latencies for read operations.
trans-unit.target: With Premium Storage, your applications can have up to 32 TB of storage per VM and achieve 50,000 IOPS (input/output operations per second) per VM with extremely low latencies for read operations.

trans-unit.source: This article gives you a guideline on how to migrate your disks, Virtual Machines (VMs) from on-premises or Standard Storage or a different cloud platform to Azure Premium Storage.
trans-unit.target: This article gives you a guideline on how to migrate your disks, Virtual Machines (VMs) from on-premises or Standard Storage or a different cloud platform to Azure Premium Storage.

trans-unit.source: To get a detailed overview of the Azure Premium Storage offering check out <link><linkText>Premium Storage: High-Performance Storage for Azure Virtual Machine Workloads</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To get a detailed overview of the Azure Premium Storage offering check out <link><linkText>Premium Storage: High-Performance Storage for Azure Virtual Machine Workloads</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Before You Begin
trans-unit.target: Before You Begin

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: You will need an Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: You will need an Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: If you don’t have one, you can create a one month <link><linkText>free trial</linkText><title></title></link> subscription or visit <link><linkText>Azure Pricing</linkText><title></title></link> for more options.
trans-unit.target: If you don’t have one, you can create a one month <link><linkText>free trial</linkText><title></title></link> subscription or visit <link><linkText>Azure Pricing</linkText><title></title></link> for more options.

trans-unit.source: To execute PowerShell cmdlets you will need the Microsoft Azure PowerShell module.
trans-unit.target: To execute PowerShell cmdlets you will need the Microsoft Azure PowerShell module.

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>Microsoft Azure Downloads</linkText><title></title></link> to download the module.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>Microsoft Azure Downloads</linkText><title></title></link> to download the module.

trans-unit.source: When you plan to use Azure VMs running on Premium Storage, you need to use the DS-series VMs.
trans-unit.target: When you plan to use Azure VMs running on Premium Storage, you need to use the DS-series VMs.

trans-unit.source: You can use both Standard and Premium Storage disks with DS-series VMs.
trans-unit.target: You can use both Standard and Premium Storage disks with DS-series VMs.

trans-unit.source: Premium storage disks will be available with more VM types in the future.
trans-unit.target: Premium storage disks will be available with more VM types in the future.

trans-unit.source: For more information on all available Azure VM disk types and sizes, see <link><linkText>Virtual Machine and Cloud Service Sizes for Azure</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on all available Azure VM disk types and sizes, see <link><linkText>Virtual Machine and Cloud Service Sizes for Azure</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Considerations
trans-unit.target: Considerations

trans-unit.source: VM sizes
trans-unit.target: VM sizes

trans-unit.source: Summarized below are the DS-series VM sizes and their characteristics.
trans-unit.target: Summarized below are the DS-series VM sizes and their characteristics.

trans-unit.source: Review the performance characteristics of these Premium Storage offerings and choose the most appropriate option for your Azure disks and VM that best suits your workload.
trans-unit.target: Review the performance characteristics of these Premium Storage offerings and choose the most appropriate option for your Azure disks and VM that best suits your workload.

trans-unit.source: Make sure that there is sufficient bandwidth available on your VM to drive the disk traffic.
trans-unit.target: Make sure that there is sufficient bandwidth available on your VM to drive the disk traffic.

trans-unit.source: VM Size
trans-unit.target: VM Size

trans-unit.target: CPU cores

trans-unit.target: Max.

trans-unit.target: STANDARD_DS12

trans-unit.target: 128 MB per second

trans-unit.target: 256 MB per second

trans-unit.target: STANDARD_DS14

trans-unit.target: 512 MB per second

trans-unit.source: Disk sizes
trans-unit.target: Disk sizes

trans-unit.source: There are three types of disks that can be used with your VM and each has specific IOPs and throughout limits.
trans-unit.target: There are three types of disks that can be used with your VM and each has specific IOPs and throughout limits.

trans-unit.source: Take into consideration these limits when choosing the disk type for your VM based on the needs of your application in terms of capacity, performance, scalability, and peak loads.
trans-unit.target: Take into consideration these limits when choosing the disk type for your VM based on the needs of your application in terms of capacity, performance, scalability, and peak loads.

trans-unit.source: Premium Storage Disk Type
trans-unit.target: Premium Storage Disk Type

trans-unit.source: Disk size
trans-unit.target: Disk size

trans-unit.source: 128 GB
trans-unit.target: 128 GB

trans-unit.source: 512 GB
trans-unit.target: 512 GB

trans-unit.source: IOPS per disk
trans-unit.target: IOPS per disk

trans-unit.source: Throughput per disk
trans-unit.target: Throughput per disk

trans-unit.source: 100 MB per second
trans-unit.target: 100 MB per second

trans-unit.source: 150 MB per second
trans-unit.target: 150 MB per second

trans-unit.source: 200 MB per second
trans-unit.target: 200 MB per second

trans-unit.source: Storage Account Scalability Targets
trans-unit.target: Storage Account Scalability Targets

trans-unit.source: Premium Storage accounts have following scalability targets in addition to the <link><linkText>Azure Storage Scalability and Performance Targets</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Premium Storage accounts have following scalability targets in addition to the <link><linkText>Azure Storage Scalability and Performance Targets</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: If your application requirements exceed the scalability targets of a single storage account, build your application to use multiple storage accounts, and partition your data across those storage accounts.
trans-unit.target: If your application requirements exceed the scalability targets of a single storage account, build your application to use multiple storage accounts, and partition your data across those storage accounts.

trans-unit.source: Total Account Capacity
trans-unit.target: Total Account Capacity

trans-unit.source: Total Bandwidth for a Locally Redundant Storage Account
trans-unit.target: Total Bandwidth for a Locally Redundant Storage Account

trans-unit.source: Disk capacity: 35TB<html></html>Snapshot capacity: 10 TB
trans-unit.target: Disk capacity: 35TB<html></html>Snapshot capacity: 10 TB

trans-unit.source: Up to 50 gigabits per second for Inbound + Outbound
trans-unit.target: Up to 50 gigabits per second for Inbound + Outbound

trans-unit.source: For the more information on Premium Storage specifications, check out <link><linkText>Scalability and Performance Targets when using Premium Storage</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For the more information on Premium Storage specifications, check out <link><linkText>Scalability and Performance Targets when using Premium Storage</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Additional Data Disks
trans-unit.target: Additional Data Disks

trans-unit.source: Depending on your workload, determine if additional data disks are necessary for your VM.
trans-unit.target: Depending on your workload, determine if additional data disks are necessary for your VM.

trans-unit.source: You can attach several persistent data disks to your VM.
trans-unit.target: You can attach several persistent data disks to your VM.

trans-unit.source: If needed, you can stripe across the disks to increase the capacity and performance of the volume.
trans-unit.target: If needed, you can stripe across the disks to increase the capacity and performance of the volume.

trans-unit.source: If you stripe Premium Storage data disks using <link><linkText>Storage Spaces</linkText><title></title></link>, you should configure it with one column for each disk that is used.
trans-unit.target: If you stripe Premium Storage data disks using <link><linkText>Storage Spaces</linkText><title></title></link>, you should configure it with one column for each disk that is used.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, overall performance of the striped volume may be lower than expected due to uneven distribution of traffic across the disks.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, overall performance of the striped volume may be lower than expected due to uneven distribution of traffic across the disks.

trans-unit.source: For Linux VMs you can use the mdadm utility to achieve the same.
trans-unit.target: For Linux VMs you can use the mdadm utility to achieve the same.

trans-unit.source: See article <link><linkText>Configure Software RAID on Linux</linkText><title></title></link> for details.
trans-unit.target: See article <link><linkText>Configure Software RAID on Linux</linkText><title></title></link> for details.

trans-unit.source: Disk Caching Policy
trans-unit.target: Disk Caching Policy

trans-unit.source: By default, disk caching policy is Read-Only for all the Premium data disks, and Read-Write for the Premium operating system disk attached to the VM.
trans-unit.target: By default, disk caching policy is Read-Only for all the Premium data disks, and Read-Write for the Premium operating system disk attached to the VM.

trans-unit.source: This configuration setting is recommended to achieve the optimal performance for your application’s IOs.
trans-unit.target: This configuration setting is recommended to achieve the optimal performance for your application’s IOs.

trans-unit.source: For write-heavy or write-only data disks (such as SQL Server log files), disable disk caching so that you can achieve better application performance.
trans-unit.target: For write-heavy or write-only data disks (such as SQL Server log files), disable disk caching so that you can achieve better application performance.

trans-unit.source: The cache settings for existing data disks can be updated using Azure Portal or the -HostCaching parameter of the Set-AzureDataDisk cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: The cache settings for existing data disks can be updated using Azure Portal or the -HostCaching parameter of the Set-AzureDataDisk cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Location
trans-unit.target: Location

trans-unit.source: Pick a location where Azure Premium Storage is available.
trans-unit.target: Pick a location where Azure Premium Storage is available.

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>Important Things to know about Premium Storage</linkText><title></title></link> for up to date information on available locations.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>Important Things to know about Premium Storage</linkText><title></title></link> for up to date information on available locations.

trans-unit.source: VMs located in the same region as the Storage account that stores the disks for VM, will give superior performance than if they are in separate regions.
trans-unit.target: VMs located in the same region as the Storage account that stores the disks for VM, will give superior performance than if they are in separate regions.

trans-unit.source: Other Azure VM configuration settings
trans-unit.target: Other Azure VM configuration settings

trans-unit.source: When creating an Azure VM you will be asked to configure certain VM settings.
trans-unit.target: When creating an Azure VM you will be asked to configure certain VM settings.

trans-unit.source: Remember, there are few settings that are fixed for the lifetime of the VM, while you can modify or add others later.
trans-unit.target: Remember, there are few settings that are fixed for the lifetime of the VM, while you can modify or add others later.

trans-unit.source: Review these Azure VM configuration settings and make sure that these are configured appropriately to match your workload requirements.
trans-unit.target: Review these Azure VM configuration settings and make sure that these are configured appropriately to match your workload requirements.

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>VM configuration settings</linkText><title></title></link> for more details.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>VM configuration settings</linkText><title></title></link> for more details.

trans-unit.source: Prepare VHDs for Migration
trans-unit.target: Prepare VHDs for Migration

trans-unit.source: The following section provides guidelines to prepare VHDs from your VM so they are ready to migrate.
trans-unit.target: The following section provides guidelines to prepare VHDs from your VM so they are ready to migrate.

trans-unit.source: The VHD may be:
trans-unit.target: The VHD may be:

trans-unit.source: A generalized operating system image that can be used to create multiple Azure VMs.
trans-unit.target: A generalized operating system image that can be used to create multiple Azure VMs.

trans-unit.source: An operating system disk that can be used with a single Azure virtual machine instance.
trans-unit.target: An operating system disk that can be used with a single Azure virtual machine instance.

trans-unit.source: A data disk that can be attached to an Azure VM for persistent storage.
trans-unit.target: A data disk that can be attached to an Azure VM for persistent storage.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: To migrate your VMs, you'll need:
trans-unit.target: To migrate your VMs, you'll need:

trans-unit.source: An Azure subscription, a storage account, and a container in that storage account to copy your VHD to.
trans-unit.target: An Azure subscription, a storage account, and a container in that storage account to copy your VHD to.

trans-unit.source: Note that the destination storage account can be a Standard or Premium Storage account depending on your requirement.
trans-unit.target: Note that the destination storage account can be a Standard or Premium Storage account depending on your requirement.

trans-unit.source: A tool to generalize VHD if you plan to create multiple VM instances from it.
trans-unit.target: A tool to generalize VHD if you plan to create multiple VM instances from it.

trans-unit.source: For example, sysprep for Windows or virt-sysprep for Ubuntu.
trans-unit.target: For example, sysprep for Windows or virt-sysprep for Ubuntu.

trans-unit.source: A tool to upload the VHD file to the Storage account.
trans-unit.target: A tool to upload the VHD file to the Storage account.

trans-unit.source: For example, <link><linkText>AzCopy</linkText><title></title></link> or <link><linkText>Azure storage explorer</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For example, <link><linkText>AzCopy</linkText><title></title></link> or <link><linkText>Azure storage explorer</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: This guide describes copying your VHD using the AzCopy tool.
trans-unit.target: This guide describes copying your VHD using the AzCopy tool.

trans-unit.source: For optimal performance, copy your VHD by running one of these tools from an Azure VM that is in the same region as the destination storage account.
trans-unit.target: For optimal performance, copy your VHD by running one of these tools from an Azure VM that is in the same region as the destination storage account.

trans-unit.source: If you are copying a VHD from an Azure VM in a different region, your performance may be slower.
trans-unit.target: If you are copying a VHD from an Azure VM in a different region, your performance may be slower.

trans-unit.source: For copying a large amount of data over limited bandwidth, consider using the <link><linkText>Microsoft Azure Import/Export service</linkText><title></title></link> to transfer your data by shipping hard disk drives to an Azure datacenter.
trans-unit.target: For copying a large amount of data over limited bandwidth, consider using the <link><linkText>Microsoft Azure Import/Export service</linkText><title></title></link> to transfer your data by shipping hard disk drives to an Azure datacenter.

trans-unit.source: You can use the Azure Import/Export service to copy data to a standard storage account only.
trans-unit.target: You can use the Azure Import/Export service to copy data to a standard storage account only.

trans-unit.source: Once the data is in your standard storage account, you can use either the <link><linkText>Copy Blob API</linkText><title></title></link> or AzCopy to transfer the data to your premium storage account.
trans-unit.target: Once the data is in your standard storage account, you can use either the <link><linkText>Copy Blob API</linkText><title></title></link> or AzCopy to transfer the data to your premium storage account.

trans-unit.source: Note that Microsoft Azure only supports fixed size VHD files.
trans-unit.target: Note that Microsoft Azure only supports fixed size VHD files.

trans-unit.source: VHDX files or dynamic VHDs are not supported.
trans-unit.target: VHDX files or dynamic VHDs are not supported.

trans-unit.source: If you have a dynamic VHD, you can convert it to fixed size using the <link><linkText>Convert-VHD</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: If you have a dynamic VHD, you can convert it to fixed size using the <link><linkText>Convert-VHD</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Scenarios for preparing VHDs
trans-unit.target: Scenarios for preparing VHDs

trans-unit.source: Below we walk through some scenarios for preparing your VHDs.
trans-unit.target: Below we walk through some scenarios for preparing your VHDs.

trans-unit.source: Generalized Operating System VHD to create multiple VM instances
trans-unit.target: Generalized Operating System VHD to create multiple VM instances

trans-unit.source: If you are uploading a VHD that will be used to create multiple generic Azure VM instances, you must first generalize VHD using a sysprep utility.
trans-unit.target: If you are uploading a VHD that will be used to create multiple generic Azure VM instances, you must first generalize VHD using a sysprep utility.

trans-unit.source: This applies to a VHD that is on-premise or in the cloud.
trans-unit.target: This applies to a VHD that is on-premise or in the cloud.

trans-unit.source: Sysprep removes any machine specific information from the VHD.
trans-unit.target: Sysprep removes any machine specific information from the VHD.

trans-unit.source: Take a snapshot or backup your VM before generalizing it.
trans-unit.target: Take a snapshot or backup your VM before generalizing it.

trans-unit.source: Running sysprep will delete the VM instance.
trans-unit.target: Running sysprep will delete the VM instance.

trans-unit.source: Follow steps below to sysprep a Windows OS VHD.
trans-unit.target: Follow steps below to sysprep a Windows OS VHD.

trans-unit.source: Note that running the Sysprep command will require you to shut down the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Note that running the Sysprep command will require you to shut down the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: For more information about Sysprep, see <link><linkText>Sysprep Overview</linkText><title></title></link> or <link><linkText>Sysprep Technical Reference</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about Sysprep, see <link><linkText>Sysprep Overview</linkText><title></title></link> or <link><linkText>Sysprep Technical Reference</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Open a Command Prompt window as an administrator.
trans-unit.target: Open a Command Prompt window as an administrator.

trans-unit.source: Enter the following command to open Sysprep:
trans-unit.target: Enter the following command to open Sysprep:

trans-unit.source: In the System Preparation Tool, select Enter System Out-of-Box Experience (OOBE), select the Generalize check box, select Shutdown, and then click OK, as shown in the image below.
trans-unit.target: In the System Preparation Tool, select Enter System Out-of-Box Experience (OOBE), select the Generalize check box, select Shutdown, and then click OK, as shown in the image below.

trans-unit.source: This will generalize the operating system and shut down the system.
trans-unit.target: This will generalize the operating system and shut down the system.

trans-unit.source: For an Ubuntu VM, use virt-sysprep to achieve the same.
trans-unit.target: For an Ubuntu VM, use virt-sysprep to achieve the same.

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>virt-sysprep</linkText><title></title></link> for more details.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>virt-sysprep</linkText><title></title></link> for more details.

trans-unit.source: See also some of the open source <link><linkText>Linux Server Provisioning software</linkText><title></title></link> for other Linux operating systems.
trans-unit.target: See also some of the open source <link><linkText>Linux Server Provisioning software</linkText><title></title></link> for other Linux operating systems.

trans-unit.source: Unique Operating System VHD to create a single VM instance
trans-unit.target: Unique Operating System VHD to create a single VM instance

trans-unit.source: If you have an application running on the VM which requires the machine specific data, do not generalize the VHD.
trans-unit.target: If you have an application running on the VM which requires the machine specific data, do not generalize the VHD.

trans-unit.source: A non-generalized VHD can be used to create a unique Azure VM instance.
trans-unit.target: A non-generalized VHD can be used to create a unique Azure VM instance.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you have Domain Controller on your VHD, executing sysprep will make it ineffective as a Domain Controller.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you have Domain Controller on your VHD, executing sysprep will make it ineffective as a Domain Controller.

trans-unit.source: Review the applications running on your VM and impact of sysprep on them before generalizing VHD.
trans-unit.target: Review the applications running on your VM and impact of sysprep on them before generalizing VHD.

trans-unit.source: Data disk VHDs to be attached to VM instance(s)
trans-unit.target: Data disk VHDs to be attached to VM instance(s)

trans-unit.source: If you have data disks in a cloud storage to be migrated you must make sure the VMs that use these data disks must be shut down.
trans-unit.target: If you have data disks in a cloud storage to be migrated you must make sure the VMs that use these data disks must be shut down.

trans-unit.source: For data disks that are on-premise, create a consistent VHD.
trans-unit.target: For data disks that are on-premise, create a consistent VHD.

trans-unit.source: Copy VHDs to Azure Storage
trans-unit.target: Copy VHDs to Azure Storage

trans-unit.source: Now that the VHD is ready, follow the steps described below to upload VHD to Azure Storage and register it as an operating system image, provisioned operating system disk, or provisioned data disk.
trans-unit.target: Now that the VHD is ready, follow the steps described below to upload VHD to Azure Storage and register it as an operating system image, provisioned operating system disk, or provisioned data disk.

trans-unit.source: Create the destination for your VHD
trans-unit.target: Create the destination for your VHD

trans-unit.source: Create a storage account for maintaining your VHDs.
trans-unit.target: Create a storage account for maintaining your VHDs.

trans-unit.source: Take into account the following points when planning where to store your VHDs:
trans-unit.target: Take into account the following points when planning where to store your VHDs:

trans-unit.source: The target storage account could be standard or premium storage depending on your application requirement.
trans-unit.target: The target storage account could be standard or premium storage depending on your application requirement.

trans-unit.source: The storage account location must be same as the DS-series Azure VMs you will create in the final stage.
trans-unit.target: The storage account location must be same as the DS-series Azure VMs you will create in the final stage.

trans-unit.source: You could copy to a new storage account, or plan to use the same storage account based on your needs.
trans-unit.target: You could copy to a new storage account, or plan to use the same storage account based on your needs.

trans-unit.source: Copy and save the storage account key of the destination storage account for the next stage.
trans-unit.target: Copy and save the storage account key of the destination storage account for the next stage.

trans-unit.source: For data disks, you can choose to keep some data disks in a standard storage account (for example, disks that have cooler storage), and move disks with heavy IOPS to a premium storage account.
trans-unit.target: For data disks, you can choose to keep some data disks in a standard storage account (for example, disks that have cooler storage), and move disks with heavy IOPS to a premium storage account.

trans-unit.source: Copy your VHD from the source
trans-unit.target: Copy your VHD from the source

trans-unit.source: Below we describe some scenarios for copying your VHD.
trans-unit.target: Below we describe some scenarios for copying your VHD.

trans-unit.source: Copy VHD from Azure Storage
trans-unit.target: Copy VHD from Azure Storage

trans-unit.source: If you are migrating VHD from a Standard Azure storage account to a Premium Azure storage account, you must copy the source path of VHD container, the VHD file name and the storage account key of the source storage account.
trans-unit.target: If you are migrating VHD from a Standard Azure storage account to a Premium Azure storage account, you must copy the source path of VHD container, the VHD file name and the storage account key of the source storage account.

trans-unit.source: Go to Azure Portal > Virtual Machines > Disks.
trans-unit.target: Go to Azure Portal > Virtual Machines > Disks.

trans-unit.source: Copy and save the VHD’s container URL from the Location column.
trans-unit.target: Copy and save the VHD’s container URL from the Location column.

trans-unit.source: The container URL will be similar to https://myaccount.blob.core.windows.net/mycontainer/.
trans-unit.target: The container URL will be similar to https://myaccount.blob.core.windows.net/mycontainer/.

trans-unit.source: Copy VHD from non-Azure Cloud
trans-unit.target: Copy VHD from non-Azure Cloud

trans-unit.source: If you are migrating VHD from non-Azure Cloud Storage to Azure, you must first export the VHD to a local directory.
trans-unit.target: If you are migrating VHD from non-Azure Cloud Storage to Azure, you must first export the VHD to a local directory.

trans-unit.source: Copy the complete source path of local directory where VHD is stored.
trans-unit.target: Copy the complete source path of local directory where VHD is stored.

trans-unit.source: If you are using AWS, export the EC2 instance to a VHD in an Amazon S3 bucket.
trans-unit.target: If you are using AWS, export the EC2 instance to a VHD in an Amazon S3 bucket.

trans-unit.source: Follow the steps described in the Amazon documentation for <link><linkText>Exporting Amazon EC2 Instances</linkText><title></title></link> to install the Amazon EC2 command-line interface (CLI) tool and run the command to export the EC2 instance to a VHD file.
trans-unit.target: Follow the steps described in the Amazon documentation for <link><linkText>Exporting Amazon EC2 Instances</linkText><title></title></link> to install the Amazon EC2 command-line interface (CLI) tool and run the command to export the EC2 instance to a VHD file.

trans-unit.source: Be sure to use VHD for the DISK_IMAGE_FORMAT variable when running the command.
trans-unit.target: Be sure to use VHD for the DISK_IMAGE_FORMAT variable when running the command.

trans-unit.source: The exported VHD file is saved in the Amazon S3 bucket you designate during that process.
trans-unit.target: The exported VHD file is saved in the Amazon S3 bucket you designate during that process.

trans-unit.source: Download the VHD file from the S3 bucket.
trans-unit.target: Download the VHD file from the S3 bucket.

trans-unit.source: Select the VHD file, then Actions > Download.
trans-unit.target: Select the VHD file, then Actions > Download.

trans-unit.source: <linkText></linkText>|
trans-unit.target: <linkText></linkText>|

trans-unit.source: Copy a VHD from On-Premise
trans-unit.target: Copy a VHD from On-Premise

trans-unit.source: If you are migrating VHD from an on premise environment, you will need the complete source path where VHD is stored.
trans-unit.target: If you are migrating VHD from an on premise environment, you will need the complete source path where VHD is stored.

trans-unit.source: This could be a server location or file share.
trans-unit.target: This could be a server location or file share.

trans-unit.source: Copy a VHD with AzCopy
trans-unit.target: Copy a VHD with AzCopy

trans-unit.source: Using AzCopy you can easily upload the VHD over the Internet.
trans-unit.target: Using AzCopy you can easily upload the VHD over the Internet.

trans-unit.source: Depending on the size of the VHDs, this may take time.
trans-unit.target: Depending on the size of the VHDs, this may take time.

trans-unit.source: Remember to check the storage account ingress/egress limits when using this option.
trans-unit.target: Remember to check the storage account ingress/egress limits when using this option.

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>Azure Storage Scalability and Performance Targets</linkText><title></title></link> for details.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>Azure Storage Scalability and Performance Targets</linkText><title></title></link> for details.

trans-unit.source: Download and install AzCopy from here: <link><linkText>Latest version of AzCopy</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: Download and install AzCopy from here: <link><linkText>Latest version of AzCopy</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: Open Azure PowerShell and go to the folder where AzCopy is installed.
trans-unit.target: Open Azure PowerShell and go to the folder where AzCopy is installed.

trans-unit.source: Use the following command to copy the VHD file from "Source" to "Destination".
trans-unit.target: Use the following command to copy the VHD file from "Source" to "Destination".

trans-unit.source: Here are descriptions of the parameters used in the AzCopy command:
trans-unit.target: Here are descriptions of the parameters used in the AzCopy command:

trans-unit.source: /Source: *:* Location of the folder or storage container URL that contains the VHD.
trans-unit.target: /Source: *:* Location of the folder or storage container URL that contains the VHD.

trans-unit.source: /SourceKey: *:* Storage account key of the source storage account.
trans-unit.target: /SourceKey: *:* Storage account key of the source storage account.

trans-unit.source: /Dest: *:* Storage container URL to copy the VHD to.
trans-unit.target: /Dest: *:* Storage container URL to copy the VHD to.

trans-unit.source: /DestKey: *:* Storage account key of the destination storage account.
trans-unit.target: /DestKey: *:* Storage account key of the destination storage account.

trans-unit.source: /BlobType: page: Specifies that the destination is a page blob.
trans-unit.target: /BlobType: page: Specifies that the destination is a page blob.

trans-unit.source: /Pattern: *:* Specify the file name of the VHD to copy.
trans-unit.target: /Pattern: *:* Specify the file name of the VHD to copy.

trans-unit.source: For details on using AzCopy tool, see <link><linkText>Getting Started with the AzCopy Command-Line Utility</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For details on using AzCopy tool, see <link><linkText>Getting Started with the AzCopy Command-Line Utility</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Other options for uploading a VHD
trans-unit.target: Other options for uploading a VHD

trans-unit.source: You can also upload a VHD to your storage account using one of the following means:
trans-unit.target: You can also upload a VHD to your storage account using one of the following means:

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Azure Storage Copy Blob API</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Azure Storage Copy Blob API</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Azure Import/Export Service</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Azure Import/Export Service</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: Import/Export can be used to copy to only standard storage account.
trans-unit.target: Import/Export can be used to copy to only standard storage account.

trans-unit.source: You will need to copy from standard storage to premium storage account using a tool like AzCopy.
trans-unit.target: You will need to copy from standard storage to premium storage account using a tool like AzCopy.

trans-unit.source: Create Azure VMs using Premium Storage
trans-unit.target: Create Azure VMs using Premium Storage

trans-unit.source: After the VHD is uploaded to the desired storage account, follow the instructions in this section to register the VHD as an OS image, or OS disk depending on your scenario and then create a VM instance from it.
trans-unit.target: After the VHD is uploaded to the desired storage account, follow the instructions in this section to register the VHD as an OS image, or OS disk depending on your scenario and then create a VM instance from it.

trans-unit.source: The data disk VHD can be attached to the VM once it is created.
trans-unit.target: The data disk VHD can be attached to the VM once it is created.

trans-unit.source: Register your VHD
trans-unit.target: Register your VHD

trans-unit.source: In order to create a VM from OS VHD or to attach a data disk to a new VM, you must first register them.
trans-unit.target: In order to create a VM from OS VHD or to attach a data disk to a new VM, you must first register them.

trans-unit.source: Follow steps below depending on your scenario.
trans-unit.target: Follow steps below depending on your scenario.

trans-unit.source: Generalized Operating System VHD to create multiple Azure VM instances
trans-unit.target: Generalized Operating System VHD to create multiple Azure VM instances

trans-unit.source: After generalized OS image VHD is uploaded to storage account, register it as an Azure VM Image so that you can create one or more VM instances from it.
trans-unit.target: After generalized OS image VHD is uploaded to storage account, register it as an Azure VM Image so that you can create one or more VM instances from it.

trans-unit.source: Use the following PowerShell cmdlets to register your VHD as an Azure VM OS image.
trans-unit.target: Use the following PowerShell cmdlets to register your VHD as an Azure VM OS image.

trans-unit.source: Provide the complete container URL where VHD was copied to.
trans-unit.target: Provide the complete container URL where VHD was copied to.

trans-unit.source: Copy and save the name of this new Azure VM Image.
trans-unit.target: Copy and save the name of this new Azure VM Image.

trans-unit.source: In the example above, it is OSImageName.
trans-unit.target: In the example above, it is OSImageName.

trans-unit.source: Unique Operating System VHD to create a single Azure VM instance
trans-unit.target: Unique Operating System VHD to create a single Azure VM instance

trans-unit.source: After the unique OS VHD is uploaded to storage account, register it as an Azure OS Disk so that you can create a VM instance from it.
trans-unit.target: After the unique OS VHD is uploaded to storage account, register it as an Azure OS Disk so that you can create a VM instance from it.

trans-unit.source: Use these PowerShell cmdlets to register your VHD as an Azure OS Disk.
trans-unit.target: Use these PowerShell cmdlets to register your VHD as an Azure OS Disk.

trans-unit.source: Provide the complete container URL where VHD was copied to.
trans-unit.target: Provide the complete container URL where VHD was copied to.

trans-unit.source: Copy and save the name of this new Azure OS Disk.
trans-unit.target: Copy and save the name of this new Azure OS Disk.

trans-unit.source: In the example above, it is OSDisk.
trans-unit.target: In the example above, it is OSDisk.

trans-unit.source: Data Disk VHD to be attached to new Azure VM instance(s)
trans-unit.target: Data Disk VHD to be attached to new Azure VM instance(s)

trans-unit.source: After the data disk VHD is uploaded to storage account, register it as an Azure Data Disk so that it can be attached to your new DS Series Azure VM instance.
trans-unit.target: After the data disk VHD is uploaded to storage account, register it as an Azure Data Disk so that it can be attached to your new DS Series Azure VM instance.

trans-unit.source: Use these PowerShell cmdlets to register your VHD as an Azure Data Disk.
trans-unit.target: Use these PowerShell cmdlets to register your VHD as an Azure Data Disk.

trans-unit.source: Provide the complete container URL where VHD was copied to.
trans-unit.target: Provide the complete container URL where VHD was copied to.

trans-unit.source: Copy and save the name of this new Azure Data Disk.
trans-unit.target: Copy and save the name of this new Azure Data Disk.

trans-unit.source: In the example above, it is DataDisk.
trans-unit.target: In the example above, it is DataDisk.

trans-unit.source: Create an Azure DS-series VM
trans-unit.target: Create an Azure DS-series VM

trans-unit.source: Once the OS image or OS disk are registered, create a new DS-series Azure VM instance.
trans-unit.target: Once the OS image or OS disk are registered, create a new DS-series Azure VM instance.

trans-unit.source: You will be using the operating system image or operating system disk name that you registered.
trans-unit.target: You will be using the operating system image or operating system disk name that you registered.

trans-unit.source: Select the VM type from the Premium Storage tier.
trans-unit.target: Select the VM type from the Premium Storage tier.

trans-unit.source: In example below, we are using the Standard_DS2 VM size.
trans-unit.target: In example below, we are using the Standard_DS2 VM size.

trans-unit.source: Update the disk size to make sure it matches your capacity and performance requirements, and the available Azure disk sizes.
trans-unit.target: Update the disk size to make sure it matches your capacity and performance requirements, and the available Azure disk sizes.

trans-unit.source: Follow the step by step PowerShell cmdlets below to create the new VM.
trans-unit.target: Follow the step by step PowerShell cmdlets below to create the new VM.

trans-unit.source: First, set the common parameters:
trans-unit.target: First, set the common parameters:

trans-unit.source: First, create a cloud service in which you will be hosting your new VMs.
trans-unit.target: First, create a cloud service in which you will be hosting your new VMs.

trans-unit.source: Next, depending on your scenario, create the Azure VM instance from either the OS Image or OS Disk that you registered.
trans-unit.target: Next, depending on your scenario, create the Azure VM instance from either the OS Image or OS Disk that you registered.

trans-unit.source: Generalized Operating System VHD to create multiple Azure VM instances
trans-unit.target: Generalized Operating System VHD to create multiple Azure VM instances

trans-unit.source: Create the one or more new DS Series Azure VM instances using the Azure OS Image that you registered.
trans-unit.target: Create the one or more new DS Series Azure VM instances using the Azure OS Image that you registered.

trans-unit.source: Specify this OS Image name in the VM configuration when creating new VM as shown below.
trans-unit.target: Specify this OS Image name in the VM configuration when creating new VM as shown below.

trans-unit.source: Unique Operating System VHD to create a single Azure VM instance
trans-unit.target: Unique Operating System VHD to create a single Azure VM instance

trans-unit.source: Create a new DS series Azure VM instance using the Azure OS Disk that you registered.
trans-unit.target: Create a new DS series Azure VM instance using the Azure OS Disk that you registered.

trans-unit.source: Specify this OS Disk name in the VM configuration when creating the new VM as shown below.
trans-unit.target: Specify this OS Disk name in the VM configuration when creating the new VM as shown below.

trans-unit.source: Specify other Azure VM information, such as a cloud service, region, storage account, availability set, and caching policy.
trans-unit.target: Specify other Azure VM information, such as a cloud service, region, storage account, availability set, and caching policy.

trans-unit.source: Note that the VM instance must be co-located with associated operating system or data disks, so the selected cloud service, region, and storage account must all be in the same location as the underlying VHDs of those disks.
trans-unit.target: Note that the VM instance must be co-located with associated operating system or data disks, so the selected cloud service, region, and storage account must all be in the same location as the underlying VHDs of those disks.

trans-unit.source: Attach Data Disk
trans-unit.target: Attach Data Disk

trans-unit.source: Lastly, if you have registered data disk VHDs, attach them to the new DS-series Azure VM.
trans-unit.target: Lastly, if you have registered data disk VHDs, attach them to the new DS-series Azure VM.

trans-unit.source: Use following PowerShell cmdlet to attach data disk to the new VM and specify the caching policy.
trans-unit.target: Use following PowerShell cmdlet to attach data disk to the new VM and specify the caching policy.

trans-unit.source: In example below the caching policy is set to ReadOnly.
trans-unit.target: In example below the caching policy is set to ReadOnly.

trans-unit.source: There may be additional steps necessary to support your application that are not be covered by this guide.
trans-unit.target: There may be additional steps necessary to support your application that are not be covered by this guide.
